content.description:
Will you feel welcomed, or will they cart you off in a wagon? 

  Requires balance ... and sticky rubber! 

  Begin up the prominent wide crack, facing the trail.  Pull up onto the block to the right (if you can figure out the direct variation, wow!).  Balance out onto the face on the left - lots of small stuff to grab, none where you want it.  Transition up and left.  The upper edge is great, go for it!
content.protection: Nothing that would actually protect you.
content.location: The first route you come to, hiking up the CCC trail.

content.description: Start in the shallow groove in the middle of the face.  Shift left at the horizontal seam in the middle of the face.  Figure out how to stand on the seam.  Slap the top edge.  Mantle.  Finish on the little pillar to the right.
content.location: Start 10 feet up off the trail, right of "Welcome Wagon" and left of the chimney that demarcates the "Mongo" block.

content.description: Easy climbing to a difficult pull into a open book dihedral. Utilize slopers on the right to gain access to the book.
content.protection: One piece of gear under the roof then solo to the top.
content.location: Just left of The Byrd directly on the CCC trail.

content.description: Found to the left and around corner from the route Mongo Fury.  Climbs small rib via small but positive holds up to large horizontal then up crystalline flake to crux mantle move and then final odd groove above.  Route appears as only a number in guidebooks and is very short but well worth an on-sight lead attempt.
content.protection: Pretty good small cams in horizontals and small wires behind flake,  Wires and cams in upper groove.  First 8 feet has no gear to speak of so get a good spot.
content.location: Found to the left and around corner from the route Mongo Fury.  Next buttress back from and right of the "No Sweat" overhang route which is the first major climbable rock formation one comes to when walking up CCC trail from the East Bluff car park.

climbs.name: Mongo Fury
climbs.fa: Barry Rugo and Arturo Reyes-Perez ca. 1980

content.description: Sweet and very fun 30 feet of climbing positive but intense vertical to overhanging arete (and crack just right of arete) up into rest and big horizontals then final steep exit crack and edges.   Crux is at mid height moving off positive horizontal hand match to pull on small side pull above to get into large jugs/ledges and protruding flake rest.
content.protection: Good to excellent small to medium wires and cams.  There is a good placement about every 3 feet on this making it quite safe to lead.  It is just very strenuous to place the gear needed at crux because it's above your head and above the nice positive horizontal hand match.
content.location: Next buttress back from and right of the "No Sweat" overhang route which is the first major climbable rock formation one comes to when walking up CCC trail from the East Bluff car park.

climbs.name: The Byrd aka No Sweat Overhang
climbs.fa: tr unknown  first clean lead rich bechler,dale m,steve s. 1980?

content.description: This is on the first out cropping on your way up the trail, so it's a convenient spot to drop your pack and consume some of that cheap swill you have been carrying.  A small roof that use to be aided on pins. Bring lots of r.p.s and small wires.
content.protection: nests of oposing r.p.s and #1 stoppers,i mean cluster fuk

content.description: The first rock formation you reach as you head up the CCC trail.  The sweeping face above the trail is "Welcome Wagon" (#4 in Swartling & Mayer), while "No Sweat Overhang" is just to the left, above the trail.  "Mongo Fury" is the popular 5.10 just uphill to the right on the next block.
